displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yep and then there’s a starter – a patient starter kit. Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: And then we have to get uh, no you’re good (door closes) Patient: Okay, well God is gonna make sure, Doctor: Yeah. Patient: God is gonna make sure the insurance is taken care of – Doctor: Mm, hmm. PAT - because your wasn’t for sure about the Provenge being taken care of… Patient: …and that was like what a hundred grand. Doctor: That was a hundred grand, yeah. Patient: And so and so the insurance took it right off. Doctor: Yep. Patient: We didn’t have to go to nobody.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: it as soon as possible. Okay but the chances of that happening are very small. The biggest thing is the second chemotherapy doesn’t have any danger to the nerves. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Like this one. Because this one that’s why I worry that you’re getting ten, twelve cycles now is your – are your nerves gonna start showing tingling, numbness, things like that? Patient: Yeah cuz see Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …my feet the most yeah… Doctor: Are tingling? Patient: Yeah, yeah I’ve been getting and it shrinks and so I’m saying wow. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: What the hell man. I don’t like that feeling. I don’t like… Doctor: No. Patient: It paralyzes or something. I don’t like that feeling.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because it will create more scarring and that’s a different thing than the prostate. Patient: I had none from that da Vinci procedure. Doctor: We will, we will get in, we will get out with these samples, done. Now you know anytime we poke there’s always a downside because you’re poking… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …bleeding, infection, you could pop something, uh admission, any of the above. So… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …I don’t think it’ll happen. The radiology guys will go over that. Um from a research standpoint, we hang onto your stuff. If any point in time you’re like (pfft) Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …Otherwise we literally try to maximize as much information as possible from your stupid cancer. Patient: Well as I as I said, if… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …if, if it’s anywhere, if it’s, if it’s the same people that did the port if it’s people that as are as competent as the people that did the port, I have no problem with it at all.

Patient: I feel comfortable now. I mean. Doctor: Okay. All right. Then I think you should- Patient: As long as we can work around- Doctor: Yeah. We’ll try and work around most of those dates. If, only it becomes a problem, we may have to delay it, doing your second eye or whatever. Family Member: Because it’s all, yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Family Member: It’s almost every three weeks. Patient: Yeah. I don’t know if, yeah, if we screw up. Family Member: These are all the dates on all the different things he has to work through for cataract surgery. Doctor: Yeah. These are just the follow-ups. One week, one day, two weeks, and four weeks. Okay. That’s not a big deal. All uh. And those days are changeable. I mean, we can do Monday versus another. Family Member: Sure. Um hum. We can put off the cataract surgery, too.

Patient: Do they have people that know how to put in an IV? Doctor: Yes they do. Well yeah. Family Member: So you think it would be one IV and then all the drugs through the IV? Doctor: Right. Yeah. Family Member: That’s much better. Doctor: That way you don’t get poked five times. If you have five blood draws. Family Member: So how are you feeling about how he is doing? Patient: Disappointed. Doctor: …this is a slight set back that Xtandi didn’t last us as long as I had hoped it would. And honestly I don’t know if that is part of the sort of resistance of BRC - BRCA mutant disease or not. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Nobody does really at this point because very few people have been really treated with Xtandi up front like that. Family Member: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: that’s it. Just one time. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um and it’s proven to help improve for you to live longer. Patient: Right. Doctor: For folks just like you. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. It comes with side effects because it’s never nothing without nothing. Patient: What is the side effects? Doctor: Number one, two and three is tiredness. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And tiredness isn’t that your brain isn’t functioning, functioning great. Patient: Just physically tired?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Okay because they gave me that Ambien. I took one of them and a half of them, I slept two hours and I was back up again. Doctor: Okay so want to switch the Ambien to the Restoril? Patient: Yeah I mean if it’s gonna make me sleep through the whole night to the next morning. I’d love that because- Doctor: Okay. Patient: -I when I get my sleep I’m more active. See that’s why I lost a lot of weight because of that. Doctor: Alright so I can make one change at a time. Which one do you want to go? Do you want to go with the Oxycodone change, the Percocet, or what do you want to do? Patient: I need my OxyContin. Doctor: Yeah the OxyContin you’re gonna get no matter what. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That you keep going. Patient: Okay. Take Percocet… Doctor: Instead of the Norco.

Family Member: I don't know where she got it from. Doctor: Let me tell you because it was good. Family Member: It smells good. Doctor: Did you want one? Family Member: No. Doctor: There's more. Family Member: No, no, no, we're going to get pizza. Doctor: Why is your PSA 10?! Patient: I don’t know! Doctor: Let me whine some more. What the hell? Are you taking your pills? Patient: Mhmm. Religiously. Doctor: Are you taking four or are you taking three? Patient: Four.

Patient: Sure. Doctor: So that there’s no misunderstanding. Patient: Sure, okay, okay. On the um on that biopsy result, Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: anything of any significance? Doctor: No I mean you have I think the P10 mutation which will be helpful for us because we have a study that actually targets that group of folks. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yep so that’s already on deck. And you know the thing is as time moves on you will get that test repeated so that’s good for that moment in time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But after chemo that profile will change again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we will most likely do both. We’ll check your tissue and we now also check your circulating blood. Patient: Sure.

Patient: No, we got one last uh two weeks. Doctor: So, we’ll figure out when your next one is and you’ll come back for that for sure Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then just know you can call anytime and come back in between. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: And then the chemo we’ll just push back but just know it’s around. Patient: That’s right. Doctor: But who knows what will get developed in the meantime. Patient: Exactly, okay, alright. Doctor: Good, yeah. Patient: Um, about how long do you think this will take for them to… Doctor: To get going?

Family Member: He said he hides them. Doctor: I guess I don’t even. I didn’t even know that. Patient: Oh yeah, because I took one when I was down there and the guy (she gets after me for swiping people’s pens) Doctor: So mine are, you’re allowed to swipe. (Laughs) Patient: Yeah, you can throw these away. (chuckles) Doctor: Well I use them so much; I mean I run out of ink and then I need to be able to toss and then move on to the next one. Family Member: Yeah, yeah. HCP Okay, so these will be sent. Do we have a - Doctor: In the R___, Yeah. (Pause 10 second) Patient: Oh yeah, they’re like, the pens he has are just like Cadillacs; they’re big. Doctor: Oh okay. Patient: They’re big but they’re light-weight, and they have the new type points on them. Doctor: My gosh, you do notice stuff. Wow! Even I didn’t know that.

Patient: Uh, and then look at the other options. So, is that, is the one that is phase one is that, that window like a real tight window. That seven days from now, it’s gonna be closed? Doctor: Umm. I don’t know that. So, when I spoke to Dr. P_, all she let me know was that there was a slot. You know, that would be something that we would say once you’ve decided or that we’ve given you the consent form that we have a potential patient who’s interested, that they would save that slot for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they would, I assume, that there is going to need to be a twenty-eight day washout of your current therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, maybe that you have to repeat scans prior to that. Um, the adrenal glands. The, the big wild card there right now what I can clearly state that it is not specific. I don’t know what it is. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And again, that’s the radiologists can’t agree on what it is. Patient: So, would I have to have something done to go into the adrenal glands or, uh, the, the tests that confirm that whether it is cancer or not cancer? Doctor: Um, no. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. And then if you decided to go with chemotherapy, it would be just one of the many spots that we would watch for change in response to.

Patient: Right. Doctor: So, uh, so what I could do is talk to the pharmacist about the Xtandi and just figure out what it’s going to cost us, and look into the trials to see, uh, if we would- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I don’t know. Are you interested in doing another trial? Or are you sort of, you did a trial, and you’re ready to-? Patient: Well, no. I mean, anything that, that might help me to survive. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. I know. I know. Patient: I’m, I’m interested in. Doctor: Let me, uh- Patient: And plus it also, it, its information that could be useful to maybe help other people. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Let me find out about the, the biopsy requirements today, uh. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I know we have some trials that if you have bone, they do not, you can’t be on the trial, because they just don’t get the tissue.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Well, today, we’ve got to sort of talk about what next. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I just reviewed, again, all the scans from a month ago or so. So really what we see in you is all of the disease seems to be in the bone. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you don’t have any really anything in lymph nodes, or liver, or lung, which is, you know, good and bad. Uh, the bad part of it is, you know, it’s hard to kind of get a good sense of how things work in the bone because the scans we do are, uh, mostly telling us new spots in the bone. But they, we can’t really measure things getting bigger or smaller. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So often we think of bone as being, we have this sort of feeling that bone is worse, but mostly because we just have trouble imaging and seeing how it changes. So, uh, but it also affects some of the trials we have because those trials require biopsies of tumor tissue, and it’s really hard to get tumor tissue from the bone. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it may alter what we can do in terms of trials. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So today, I thought we could talk a little bit about kind of what the standard things are to do next, and then we could talk a little bit about some trials that we have. The typical thing we would do next is either to put you on another hormone- Patient: Um hum.

Patient: I lost five more pounds. I got to gain my weight back. Doctor: Well yeah you got to get your teeth back in. Patient: I’m going, I’m going, I’m making the appointment Thursday. I’m going and having them take these out of here. I don’t know, I might have to pay for some more because I don’t think my insurance will cover this, but I want – I’m gonna do it anyway. Doctor: See what they say. Meanwhile though I need you to be drinking those Ensure cans. Two to three a day. Patient: I got it your husband he wrote me a thing to go down there and get me two case. I’m gonna get a case of Ensure and Boost. Doctor: Good. Patient: But I’m gonna be eating and next time I come here… Doctor: Okay, good. Yeah. Patient: …I’m gonna have my weight is gonna grow back. Doctor: Alright. Good. I’m gonna hold you to it. Patient: And you know when I tell you something (laughs) Patient: You know that’s how it be doc you know that, you know that. Doctor: Okay so when did I last give you this uh medication? When are you going to go fill them?
